Chapter 8, Part 2: The Thirty-three Heavens
Bhiká¹£us!
What is the reason that those heavens have a garden called Joy?
Bhiká¹£us!

When the king of the Thirty-three Heavens enters that Joy Garden and sits on the two stones called Joy and Good Joy, his mind experiences joy, his thoughts are joyful, he thinks of it again and again, and experiences all kinds of happiness. After experiencing pleasant joy, he experiences supreme bliss. Therefore, the gods all call that garden Joy.
Bhiká¹£us!
What is the reason that those heavenly trees are called PÄrijÄta?
Bhiká¹£us!
Under that PÄrijÄta tree, there was a god-son named Mata, who day and night always enjoyed the various heavenly five desires and pleasures together.
Therefore, the gods called that tree PÄrijÄta.
Furthermore, bhiká¹£us!
Even if the Thirty-three Heavens have an emergency, they never dare to abandon the GandhamÄdana stone. They must make offerings, respect and venerate it, and then leave as they please.
Why is this?
This stone is where the TathÄgata once resided.
Therefore, the gods regard it as a caitya, because all worlds, including gods, humans, demons, BrahmÄ, Å›ramaá¹‡as, brÄhmaá¹‡as, and others, should make offerings to it.
Bhiká¹£us!

There are thirty-three celestials who can only see the PÄruá¹£aka Garden with their eyes, but their bodies cannot enter. Because their bodies do not enter, they cannot obtain the five desires and virtues of that place and experience complete happiness.
Why is this?
Because their past wholesome roots are weak, they are unable to enter.

There are thirty-three celestials who can see the PÄruá¹£aka Garden and their bodies can also enter. Having entered, they fully obtain the various five desires and virtues of that place and experience happiness.
Why is this?
Because their wholesome roots are superior.
Bhiká¹£us!

There are thirty-three celestials who cannot see the Citra-ratha Garden with their eyes, and their bodies also cannot enter. They also cannot obtain the five desires and virtues of that garden and experience happiness.
Why is this?
Because their wholesome roots are different.
There are thirty-three heavens, whose eyes can see the Colorful Chariot Garden, but their bodies cannot enter, nor can they enjoy the pleasures of the five desires and merits of that garden.
Why is this?
Because their wholesome roots are superior or inferior.

There are thirty-three heavens, whose eyes can see the Colorful Chariot Garden, and their bodies can enter. Having entered, they fully obtain the various five desires, and enjoy the pleasures of the united merits of the same body.
Why is this?
Because their wholesome roots are superior and excellent.
Bhiká¹£us!
All thirty-three heavens see the Colorful Garden, and all can enter;
Having entered, they all also obtain the various five desires and merits of that garden, and enjoy the pleasures of the united merits of the same body.
Why is this?
Because their cultivation is equal.
Because there are no different wholesome roots in that place.
Bhiká¹£us!

There are thirty-three celestials who cannot see the Joyous Garden, cannot enter it, and because they cannot enter it, they cannot experience the various pleasures of the five desires and their combined merits and perfect enjoyment there.
Why is this?
Because the fruits there are superior, and the karma created in past lives is different.

There are thirty-three celestials who see the Joyous Garden but cannot enter it, and also cannot experience the various pleasures of the five desires and their combined merits and perfect enjoyment in the Joyous Garden.
Why is this?
Because the karma of those celestials is different.

There are thirty-three celestials who see the Joyous Garden, and their bodies can enter it. Having entered, they fully experience the various pleasures of the five desires and their combined merits and perfect enjoyment, and receive them all.
Why is this?
Because the good karma cultivated by those celestials in the past is not different.
Monks!

At that time, those minor kings and celestial beings also had this thought:

At that time, Åšakra, Lord of the Devas, having seen the devas, also adorned his body with various necklaces and ornaments.

Having each sat down, Åšakra, Lord of the Devas, led the assembly of devas towards the gardens of Poluosha, Zaseche, Zalan, and Huanxi. Having arrived, they stopped.

At that time, Åšakra, Lord of the Devas, surrounded by the minor devas and the thirty-two devas, enters the gardens such as the variegated chariot and joyful, and enjoys the pleasures of play, wandering as he wishes, either sitting or reclining.

At that time, the devas will enjoy such pleasures for one day, up to seven days, for one month, up to three months, indulging in various amusements, bathing, playing, walking, standing, sitting, and lying down, going east and west as they wish.

There are seven kinds of colors in human flowers.
What are the seven?

Namely, the color of fire and the light of fire, the color of gold and the light of gold, the color of blue and the light of blue, the color of red and the light of red, the color of white and the light of white, the color of yellow and the light of yellow, and the color of black and the light of black.

All the gods have ten kinds of distinct dharmas.
What are the ten?
Bhiká¹£us!ğŸ”½First, when the gods walk, they come and go without limit;
Second, when the gods walk, they come and go without obstruction;
Third, when the gods walk, they are neither slow nor fast;
Fourth, when the gods walk, their feet leave no footprints;
Fifth, the physical strength of the gods is without the suffering of fatigue;
Sixth, the bodies of the gods have form but no shadows;
Seventh, all the gods do not defecate or urinate;
Eighth, all the gods do not have nasal mucus or saliva;
Ninth, the bodies of the gods are pure and subtle, without skin, flesh, sinews, blood vessels, fat, blood, marrow, or bones;

Tenth, the bodies of the gods can manifest long or short, blue, yellow, red, white, large or small, coarse or fine, as they wish, all beautiful and perfect, extraordinary, making people love and enjoy them.
All the bodies of the gods have these ten kinds of inconceivable things.

They soar through the air, their eyes do not blink when they look.
Their necklaces are natural, their clothes are free of dirt.

If the light of the world, whether the world of devas, mÄras, BrahmÄ, Å›ramaá¹‡as, brÄhmaá¹‡as, humans, and so forth, wishes to compare with the light of the TathÄgata, the Arhat, the Samyaksaá¹ƒbuddha, even if it were a hundred thousand koá¹­Ä«s of Ganges Rivers, it would still be incomparable.
This light of the TathÄgata is the most supreme, the most wonderful, the most special, and the foremost.
Why is it so?
Bhiká¹£us!

Because the TathÄgata's body has immeasurable precepts, immeasurable samÄdhi, prajÃ±Ä, liberation, the vision and cognition of liberation, spiritual powers, the practice of spiritual powers, teaching and transforming, the wheel of teaching and transforming, the place of teaching and the wheel of the place of teaching, and so forth, all of which are immeasurable. Bhiká¹£us!
The TathÄgata is endowed with immeasurable merits and all dharmas. For this reason, the TathÄgata's light is supreme and unsurpassed. You should uphold it like this.

All sentient beings have four kinds of food that nourish the great elements, enabling them to abide, to form various existences, and to be mutually supportive.
What are the four?
First, coarse and fine food; second, contact food; third, mental intention food; fourth, consciousness food.
What kind of sentient beings should eat coarse and fine food?
Bhiká¹£us!
The people of JambudvÄ«pa eat rice, wheat, beans, fish, and meat, which are called coarse food;
covering, massaging, bathing, rubbing, anointing with oil, and touching are called fine food.
The people of GodÄnÄ«ya and PÅ«rvavideha have coarse and fine food that is roughly the same as JambudvÄ«pa.
The people of Uttarakuru do not farm or plant, yet naturally there is ripe rice, which is their coarse food;
covering, bathing, and massage, etc., are their fine food.
Bhiká¹£us!
All dragons, garuá¸as, etc., use fish, turtles, alligators, frogs, dragons, snakes, otters, and kimbÄ«ra, etc., as their coarse food;
covering, bathing, etc., are their fine food.
The asuras use the heavenly excellent taste of sudhÄ as their coarse food;
the coverings, etc., are their fine food.
The Four Heavenly Kings and the heavenly multitudes all use the heavenly taste of sudhÄ as their coarse food;
the coverings, etc., are their fine food.
The Thirty-three Celestials still use the heavenly taste of sudhÄ as their coarse food;
the coverings, etc., are their fine food.
Like the Thirty-three Celestials, up to the YÄma Heaven, Tuá¹£ita Heaven, NirmÄá¹‡arati Heaven, ParanirmitavaÅ›avartin Heaven, and so forth, all use the flavor of their own heavens as coarse food,
and the various coverings and so forth as subtle food.
Above this, all the heavens use the joy of dhyÄna and the joy of the Dharma as food, samÄdhi as food, and samÄpatti as food, without any coarse or subtle food.
Bhiká¹£us!
What kind of sentient beings use contact as food?
Bhiká¹£us!

All sentient beings born from eggs, namely geese, swans, cranes, ducks, peacocks, parrots, mynas, doves, pigeons, sparrows, pheasants, magpies, crows, and so forth, and other various kinds of sentient beings born from eggs, all use contact as their food because their bodies are obtained from eggs.
What kind of sentient beings use intention as food?

If there are sentient beings who use thought to nourish the faculties, increase the body and life, namely fish, turtles, snakes, frogs, tortoises, and other sentient beings who use thought to benefit the faculties and increase longevity, all of these use thought as their food.
What kind of sentient beings use consciousness as food?
Namely, sentient beings in the hells and those in the heaven of infinite consciousness, these sentient beings all use consciousness to sustain them as their food.
Bhiká¹£us!
These four kinds of food sustain the great elements of sentient beings and nourish the life-faculty.
Herein is an udÄna verse:
Flower-colored and all dharmas, life, and clothing as the fifth,
Bartering and marriage, faculties, light, and food as the ten.
Bhiká¹£us!
Sentient beings in the world all have three kinds of evil conduct in common.
What are the three?
Namely, evil bodily actions, evil verbal actions, and evil mental actions.
Bhiká¹£us!

There are sentient beings who commit evil bodily actions, evil verbal actions, and evil mental actions. Due to these causes and conditions, when their bodies perish and their lives end, they fall into evil destinies and are born in the hells.
In this realm, their final consciousness ceases, and the first continuity of hell consciousness arises.
When that consciousness arises together, it is called name-and-form. Because of name-and-form, there are the six sense bases.
Bhiká¹£us!

There are also sentient beings who commit evil bodily actions, evil verbal actions, and evil mental actions. Due to these causes and conditions, when their bodies perish and their lives end, they fall into evil destinies and are born among animals.
In this realm, their final consciousness ceases, and the first continuity of animal consciousness arises.
When that consciousness arises together, it is called name-and-form. Because of name-and-form, there are the six sense bases.
Bhiká¹£us!

There are also sentient beings who commit evil bodily actions, evil verbal actions, and evil mental actions. Due to these causes and conditions, when their bodies perish and their lives end, they fall into evil destinies and are born in the world of Yama.
In this place, their final consciousness ceases, and the consciousness of the world of Yama begins to continue.
When that consciousness first arises, it is simultaneously born together with name-and-form. Because of name-and-form, there are the six sense bases.
Bhiká¹£us!
These are called the three kinds of evil actions, which should be abandoned.
Bhiká¹£us!
There are also three kinds of good conduct in the world.
What are the three?
They are good bodily conduct, good verbal conduct, and good mental conduct.
Bhiká¹£us!

There are sentient beings who perform good bodily actions, good verbal actions, and good mental actions. Due to these causes and conditions, when their bodies perish and their lives end, they are born in the human realm.
At this point, their final consciousness ceases, and the consciousness of the human realm begins to continue.
When that consciousness arises, it is born simultaneously with name-and-form, and because of the condition of name-and-form, the six sense bases come to be.
Monks!
There are also beings who perform good physical, verbal, and mental actions. Due to these causes and conditions, when their bodies perish and their lives end, they are reborn in the heavens.
Here, their consciousness ceases, and in those heavens, the consciousness begins to continue.
When that consciousness arises, it is born simultaneously with name-and-form. Because there is name-and-form, the six sense bases come to be.
Monks!

In those heavens, either in a god's body, or in a goddess' body, or in the place where they sit, or between the knees, or between the thighs, they suddenly appear. When they are first born, they are like a twelve-year-old child in the human realm.
If it is a male god, it will be born on the lap of the god, in any place.
If it is a female god, it will be born inside the thighs of the female god.
After being born, the god will say, This is my son or daughter.
It should be understood in this way.
Bhiká¹£us!

Cultivating goodness and being born in the heavens has such a principle, namely, when the god and goddess are first born, due to the perfuming of their own karmic causes, they attain three kinds of thoughts:

First, they know by themselves from where they died; second, they know by themselves in what place they are born now; third, they know that birth is the result of this karma, the reward of this merit.
Moreover, they think like this:
'Since my life in that place has ended, I have been reborn here. Because I have these three kinds of karmic results, the three karmic results have matured, and I have come to be reborn here.
What are the three?
Namely, good conduct with the body, good conduct with the speech, and good conduct with the mind.'
Because the karmic retribution of these three types of actions has matured, when their bodies perish and their lives end, they are reborn here.
He further thinks like this:
'If I die here, I wish to be reborn in the human realm.
After I am reborn in the human realm, I will again cultivate good conduct of body, speech, and mind.
Because I cultivate good conduct of body, speech, and mind, after my body perishes, I will return and be reborn here.'
After thinking like this, he next thinks of food.
When he thinks of eating, in front of him there will be jeweled vessels naturally filled with heavenly sudhÄ, with various colors.
Among the celestial beings, those with superior karmic results have sudhÄ that is the whitest and purest in color;
if that celestial being has middling karmic results, the sudhÄ will be slightly red in color;
if that celestial being has inferior blessings and virtues, the sudhÄ will be slightly black in color.
At that time, the god took some heavenly sudhÄ with his hand and put it in his mouth. As soon as the sudhÄ entered his mouth, it gradually melted and transformed.
It was just like ghee or fresh butter thrown into a fire, which immediately melts and disappears without a trace.
In the same way, the heavenly sudhÄ placed in the mouth naturally dissolved, also like that.
After eating this flavor, if there was thirst, then in front of him there was a heavenly jeweled vessel filled with heavenly wine.
The blessings were superior, middling, and inferior, white, red, and black, briefly explained as before.
Entering his mouth, it also melted in the same way.
Then, the god, having finished eating and drinking, his body gradually grew large, coarse and fine, high and low, no different from the gods and goddesses born before.
Bhiká¹£us!

These heavenly sons and heavenly maidens, their bodies already satisfied, each according to their wishes, went in various directions. Some went to the ponds, entered the ponds, bathed and purified themselves, joyfully experiencing bliss.

After coming out of the ponds, they again went to the fragrant trees. The branches of those fragrant trees naturally bent down. From the branches emerged various wonderful fragrances, flowing into their hands. The heavenly sons took them and applied them to their bodies.

After applying them to their bodies, they again went to the clothing trees. At that time, the clothing trees also bent down their branches. Between the branches, various exquisite fine garments emerged, hanging down to their hands. They took them and put them on.
After putting on the garments, they went to the jewelry trees. The trees bent down and reached their hands, also like before. They wrapped and tied them up, adorning their bodies.
They again went to the garland trees. The trees bent down and flowed out various wonderful flower garlands. The gods took them and adorned their heads.

They then went to the tree of vessels, and the tree produced various precious vessels of all kinds, which they took in their hands. They then went to the fruit grove, filled various fruits, either to eat or to drink the juice.

In this way, they then went to the musical trees, and the trees also bent down, naturally producing various musical instruments, which they took as they wished, either playing the zither or beating the drums, or singing or dancing, with a subtle sound that made people enjoy listening.
Then they went to the various groves, and after entering the grove, they saw countless hundreds, countless thousands, and countless hundreds of thousands of koá¹­is of celestial maidens.
When these celestials had not yet seen the maidens, they had knowledge and insight into the karmic retributions of their past lives, thinking:
I have come to this place from such-and-such a place, and now my body receives such and such karmic retributions.
Because the karma was ripe, at that time they clearly remembered the events of their past lives, as if looking at the palm of their hand.
Because of seeing the celestial maidens and being confused by their forms, the mind of right mindfulness and wisdom is extinguished.
Having lost this kind of recollection from the past, attached to present desires, one only utters with the mouth:
'Are all these celestial maidens?
Celestial maidens?
' This is called being bound by desire and love.
Bhiká¹£us!
These are called the three kinds of good conduct, which should be cultivated and practiced.
Bhiká¹£us!

In each month, there are six Upoá¹£adha days (Skt. poá¹£adha) that increase and grow, referring to the growth of wholesome roots by upholding the precepts. In the bright fortnight there are fifteen days, and in the dark fortnight there are also fifteen days. The two fortnights of bright and dark each have three observance days.
What are the three observance days in the bright fortnight?
They are the eighth, fourteenth, and fifteenth days of the month;
The dark fortnight also has three observance days, the same as the bright fortnight.
Why do they observe the precepts on the third day of each of the two months of white and black?
Bhiká¹£us!
In each of the two months of white and black, there are eight days. On these days, the Four Heavenly Kings gather their retinue and proclaim to them:

'You should all go and observe everywhere in the four directions. Are there any people in the world who practice filial piety and make offerings to their parents, and who respect Å›ramaá¹‡as and brÄhmaá¹‡as?
Do they revere the elders?
Do they practice giving and observe the precepts?
Do they guard the eight precepts and observe the six days of purification?

' When the Four Heavenly Kings have given these orders, the messengers accept the heavenly king's command and immediately descend to observe all human realms, who practices filial piety and makes offerings to their parents?
What clans and surnames respect Å›ramaá¹‡as and brÄhmaá¹‡as?
Moreover, in which families do men and women serve their elders and promote respectful courtesy?
Who practices giving?
Who observes the six precepts?
Who upholds the eight prohibitions?
Who guards the precepts and practices?

At that time, the messengers went through the world in order, observing. If they saw that few people in the human realm were filial and supportive of their parents, few were able to serve and respect the Å›ramaá¹‡as, few were able to honor the elders and virtuous brÄhmaá¹‡as, and few were able to revere the elders, with little generosity, few observed the fasts, guarded the precepts incompletely, and guarded the prohibitions with many omissions, then the heavenly messengers, having fully seen this, immediately returned to the Four Heavenly Kings and reported:

Your Majesties should know that in the world, all people do not have much filial piety and service to their parents, nor do they have much respect for Å›ramaá¹‡as and brÄhmaá¹‡as, nor do they have much reverence for elders and virtuous teachers and elders, nor are there many people who practice generosity and observe the six fasts, nor are there many people who uphold the precepts and guard the eight precepts.
At that time, the Four Heavenly Kings, having heard such words from the messengers, were distressed and unhappy. They replied to the messengers, saying:
If it is really so in the world, it is very bad.
Why is it so?
The lifespan of humans is extremely short, and they stay in the world for only a short time. They should cultivate goodness and turn to the next world to attain peace and happiness.
Why is it that those people now do not have much filial piety towards their parents, and cannot even practice the six days of observance and uphold the eight precepts to guard their body and speech?
This greatly diminishes our heavenly beings and further increases the asura species.ğŸ”½Bhiká¹£us!
Bhiká¹£us!

If people in the world mostly practice filial piety and make offerings to their parents, respect Å›ramaá¹‡as and brÄhmaá¹‡as, honor the elders, cultivate etiquette and courtesy, enjoy practicing generosity, delight in receiving the six days of precepts, diligently promote meritorious deeds, and always observe the eight precepts, then such practice will continue without interruption.
At that time, the heavenly messengers will inspect and report to the Four Heavenly Kings, saying:

'Great Kings, you should know that in the world, many people are filial and make offerings to their parents, many respect Å›ramaá¹‡as, brÄhmaá¹‡as, and elders, enjoy practicing generosity, and diligently cultivate precepts and observances.'
At that time, the Four Heavenly Kings, having heard this from the heavenly messengers, will be overjoyed and elated beyond measure, and say:
'Excellent, excellent!
The people in the world are able to cultivate such extreme goodness and virtue.
Why is it so?
The lifespans of those people are short, and they will soon pass on to the next world.

Now, they are able to be filial to their parents in the human realm, serve Å›ramaá¹‡as and brÄhmaá¹‡as, respect the elders, practice propriety and deference, take great pleasure in giving, uphold the precepts, and observe the fasts. In this way, they will increase the immeasurable retinue of the devas and diminish the various kinds of asuras.
Bhiká¹£us!
Why are the fourteenth days of the dark and bright fortnights called Upoá¹£adha?
Bhiká¹£us!

On the fourteenth days of the dark and bright fortnights, the Four Heavenly Kings also each summon their princes to descend to the world to observe good and evil. If good is scarce, they are sorrowful; if good is abundant, they are joyful. All is as the messengers have said, only the princes themselves descend, which is different.
Bhiká¹£us!
Why are the fifteenth days of the second month of spring and autumn also called Uposatha?
Bhiká¹£us!

On these days, the Four Heavenly Kings descend to the world themselves to examine good and evil, and having known the relative amounts, they immediately go to the assembly hall of the Thirty-three Celestials to report to Åšakra DevÄnÄm-Indra on the relative amounts of good and evil in the human realm.
At that time, if Åšakra DevÄnÄm-Indra hears that the number of people cultivating blessings in the human realm is small, he will again become distressed and unhappy. Why is it so?
The number of celestial beings will decrease, while the number of asuras will increase even more.
If he hears that the number of people acting in accordance with the Dharma in the human realm is large, his mind will be filled with immeasurable joy and he will say:
The number of celestial beings will gradually increase, while the number of asuras will gradually decrease.
Bhiká¹£us!

For this reason, on these six days, the gods descend to observe the good and evil of human beings, and should cultivate the precepts of the fast, therefore these days are called uposatha.Here is the corrected and aligned text:
Sutra on the Origin of the World, Scroll 7
